Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other in a silent accusation. My wife’s voice echoes in my mind from this morning: “Can you help fold these tonight? I’ve got a late call.” I promised I would, but now, as I open my laptop, a new message pops up—Product has scheduled a brainstorming session for tomorrow. Attendance is “optional,” but I know what that really means. If I skip it, I’ll miss out on shaping the new features, maybe even lose some credibility with the other teams. If I go, I’ll be home late, and the laundry will still be there, untouched, a quiet sign that I’m not pulling my weight at home. My chest tightens as I picture my wife’s tired face, the unspoken disappointment. I want to be a good partner, but I also want to be seen as a team player at work. I sit on the edge of the couch, laptop on my knees, laundry at my side, torn between two worlds that both expect more than I feel I can give.
